entry.title: That Time Astronauts Organized The First Strike In Space… Allegedly

media:group.media:title: That Time Astronauts Organized The First Strike In Space… Allegedly
media:group.media:description:
Henry Ford said that "Every man needs more than one day a week for rest and recreation," something that was also true for the crew working in Skylab 4 on the International Space Station back in 1973. But since every day they spent in space cost the taxpayer $4 million dollars, Houston expected value for their money - until the crew couldn't take it anymore and finally snapped.

entry.title: The Bizarre Tale of Canada's Literal Gaydar

media:group.media:title: The Bizarre Tale of Canada's Literal Gaydar
media:group.media:description:
Like most countries, Canada has its own dark past. One of these was the invention of the "Fruit Machine" - a real-life "Gaydar". For 40 years, the Fruit Machine would be used as a part of the "Gay Purge" in Canada - an attempt to remove all homosexuals and other "sexual deviants" from the civil service, the military, and the Mounted Police, that would leave deep scars on its LGBTQ+ community.
→Subscribe for new videos every day! Hit the sub button above.

entry.title: The Eunuch Who Might Have Been the Greatest of All Rome's Generals

media:group.media:title: The Eunuch Who Might Have Been the Greatest of All Rome's Generals
media:group.media:description:
By the 5th and 6th centuries, eunuchs were fulfilling important roles in Roman society. But Narses would make history by not making a name for himself as a trusted Grand Chamberlain for Emperor Justinian, but also for his military prowess, earning him a spot as one of the greatest of all Roman Generals.

entry.title: The Ugly Little Boat That Won WWII

media:group.media:title: The Ugly Little Boat That Won WWII
media:group.media:description:
During WWII, the Allies needed a landing craft that would enable them to invade open beaches in enemy territories as quickly and efficiently as possible. This came in the form of the Higgins Boat, a landing craft that had been designed by Andrew Higgins. 'the man who won the war for us'.

entry.title: Changing Views with a Weird Soviet Turntable Procedure- The Story of Radial Keratotomy

media:group.media:title: Changing Views with a Weird Soviet Turntable Procedure- The Story of Radial Keratotomy
media:group.media:description:
Eye surgery isn't a new concept. Practiced since 1750 BCE, the methods used in eye surgery didn't change much over the centuries. But in 1974, an ophthalmologist named Svyatoslav Fyodorov would take the first step in revolutionizing eye surgery, creating a possible cure for blindness.

media:group.media:title: The Jelly Donut
media:group.media:description:
During a speech delivered in Berlin, John F. Kennedy proudly stated that he would be proud to be called a Berliner, proclaiming it loudly in German to a crowd of 450 000 people. The chuckles that followed soon after gave rise to the rumor that he'd mistakenly just proclaimed to be a jelly donut, despite all evidence to the contrary.

entry.title: How Did ‘SOS’ Become The Universal Distress Signal?

media:group.media:title: How Did ‘SOS’ Become The Universal Distress Signal?
media:group.media:description:
Today, everyone knows the term 'SOS' and what it means. With the invention of telegraphs in the late 19th century, international navies quickly issued their own standard calls for distress. In this episode, we look back at the history of distress calls and explain how a maritime disaster cemented 'SOS' as the universal call for help.
